bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 12, 1874

div1.p: Reed informs Lawrence that he is studying for the Medical Corps exam. He describes the exam, and offers his opinion of social engagements.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 12, 1874
div1.p:
Believe me,
it is a genuine pleasure
to lay aside the dusty
book over whose uninter-
esting pages I have been
bending all the day long,
and to take up my pen for
a few moments. If I appear
amazingly stupid, as I pro-
ceed, please remember that
my mind has been racked,
during the past day or two,
with the “atomic theory” and
the “law of equivalents;” so
that, peradventure whatsoever
I shall send, will not con-
tain an atom of news or
be equivalent to your loss of
time in reading it.

From early morning till far
into the hours of night I must
needs be plodding along through
dry details and charging my
memory with a thousand dif-
ferent matters which may
possibly prove useful to
me in the coming ordeal.
The truth is, I was not aware
of how much I had forgot-
ten and in how many places
the rust had accumulated,
till I began a careful re-
view. The more I read, the
greater the task looms up be-
fore me, still I stand appalled
at the work that must be done,
and almost think that all
I ever knew has forsaken
me. But the one thing I will
not permit to forsake me is my
courage, and if effort will avail
anything, it shall not fail me
in this case. I went over to
New York, a few days ago, and
had a long talk with the
Recorder of the Examining Board.
To my utter astonishment, he
informed me that candidates
must stand an examination
on Latin, Greek, Mathematics
& History, in addition to med-
ical subjects. Horror of hor-
rors! Imagine me conjugating
an irregular Greek verb, or
telling what x + y equals, or
when Rome was founded,
or the battle of Marathon
was fought- why the thing is impos-
sible- I shall utterly fail.
Add to this that each ap-
plicant is examined five
hours, each day, during six
successive days-- thirty hours
questioning-- and to cap the
climax, there are more than
five hundred applicants for
less than thirty vacancies!
The very thought of it makes
me dizzy. Think of my condi-
tion and pity me; for I need
all the sympathy of all my
friends.

Thus, you perceive, my
time has been spent in quite
a different way from that
you described. No recreation,
no jollity, no gliding “softly
o'er the rippling waters,” no
listening to “wandering strains
of melody.” Your moon-light
excursion down the Meherrin
must have been quite roman-
tic. It is enough for me to
know that it was a “feast
of reason.” At such a time I
ask nothing better than to meet
with some friend. (of course,
I mean a lady-friend). Yes, some
bright, sensible woman whose
conversation is both agreeable
and entertaining, and who
will kindly permit a reward
to be interpolated, now and then.
How fast the hours speed their
flight to us unconscious. Whol-
ly absorbed within the Present,
we forget the annoyances of
the Past and care not for
the revelations of the Future.
In after days, we look back
with unallayed delight, and
remember such occassions as
the oases in life's desert. But if,
per contra, one cannot sit
quietly and chat a friend, but
is expected to fly here and
there, like a bee in Spring-time,
and gather pleasure from the
conversation of a dozen; how
unfortunate is the lot of such
an one! For me the result
would be a cup of bitters.
And, just here, an idea occurs
to me which, with your permis-
sion, I will pursue briefly.
I sometimes think that I am
a peculiar mortal. Perhaps I
am invited to be present at a
party, composed of ladies and
gentlemen, assembled for the pur-
pose of spending an evening in
pleasant social intercourse.
I go with the determination to
act my part as well as I can,
with no malice in my heart
toward any living soul. I arrive
and am a ushered into a
brilliantly lighted parlor
where are seated a dozen or
more prettily dressed young
ladies and as many starchy
looking young gentlemen; the
buds of modern society.
Every one seems in the best of
humor, and I, too, enter into the
mirth of the occassion. As the
conversation quickly flies from
one topic to another, listen for
a moment. Yon fair one is going
into ecstasy over the last Sara-
toga Boat Race, and that
flashily-dressed young gen-
tleman is expatiating with all
his powers of eloquence about
the grandeur of some recent
Ball. Perchance there is a lull
in the conversation, when forth-
with a damsel to the piano
hies and, for the edification
of all, drums away at an operatic
air with all her might. Should
any one be so forgetful as
to suggest a topic of interest,
he soon finds himself without
any audience. They say you are
too serious. And thus the hours
pass, till finally the time of
departure arrives, when expres-
sing ourselfves as being pleased,
beyond measure, with the evening's
entertainment, & bidding many
adieus, we depart. I loiter home
slowly, and muse by the way-
side. I wonder, how in the name
of all that is sensible, can
people be entertained with
such silly frivolous conver-
sation! Can mortal man or
woman grow wiser by listening
to such shallow, superficial
nothingness! Is there no germ
of advancement implanted
in the bosoms of such creatures?
Is there no longing desire to
add to their store of information?
If so, why are they satisfied with
babbling such a lot of foolish-
ness! Is it possible that exter-
nal realities merely give rise
in them to a sensation, and this
is converted into so many move-
ments of the tongue, without
any thought being involved in
the process from beginning to
end! Verily, it so seemeth! Thus
musing, I reach my door. The
thought occurs to me that I may
be too unappreciative and I
would gladly thus construe
it. Yet, I cannot hide my ut-
ter disappointment in having
thrown away another evening.
I feel that, rather than un-
dergo a repetition of the same,
I would prefer that “a mill-stone
be hanged about my neck
and that I be drowned in
the depths of the sea.”

And since I have hung this
“mill-stone” about my neck, I
begin to feel the weight of it.
Under these circumstances, you
could not expect me to continue
my letter. You may regret that
I did not find my burden sooner.
Regarding this latter conclusion
as the most probable, I will
stop, but not before begging
that you will excuse this
hastily and miserably written
letter, and

closer.salute:
believe me, as ever,
with much respect,
